Description: A strong chisel: of rectangular section, with the maximum thickness just below the centre, tapering to a narrow cutting edge. The edge has been worked from both sides of the tool.
Curator's comments: This chisel, omitted by Petrie from his report in 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), is similar to the style of chisel of the Third Dynasty, with an increase in thickness in relation to the width. Compare J. Garstang, ‘Maḥâsna and Bêt Khallâf’ (London, 1989), pls.XVI, 23, 24; XXIII, 34. For other examples of Early Dynastic copper chisels, see E. Amélineau, ‘Les Nouvelles Fouilles d’Abydos’ II (1896-7), pl.XVIII; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pl.XXXV, 91; XXXVIII, 94; XLI, 93; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), pl.L; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' II (London, 1902-4), pl.XV, 1, 8, 10; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tombs of the courtiers and Oxyrhynkos' (London, 1925), pl.V, 6, 8, 12; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tarkhan I and Memphis V' (London, 1913), pls.IV, 3-5, 8; VI, 4, 10; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tools and weapons : illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University College, London' (London, 1917), 19-20 and pls.XXI-XXII; G. A. Reisner, 'The early dynastic cemeteries of Naga-ed-Dêr' I, (California, 1908), 115 and pl.40d; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' I' (Cairo, 1949), 42-6 and pl.9B; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' II' (London, 1954), 61 and pl.XXXIb; J. E. Quibell, ‘Archaic Objects’ (Cairo, 1905), nos. 14540-1. 14556-7 and pl.59; J. E. Quibell, 'Excavations at Saqqara, 1912-1914: Archaic Mastabas’ (Cairo, 1923), pl.VIII, 1; J. E. Quibell & F. W. Green, 'Hierakonpolis' II (London, 1989), 26 and pl.XLVIIIb; C. M. Firth and J. E. Quibell, 'Excavations at Saqqara : the Step Pyramid' II (Cairo, 1935), pl.93, (3); J. Garstang, ‘Maḥâsna and Bêt Khallâf’ (London, 1989), pls.XVI, XXIII; P. Montet, 'Kêmi' 8 (1946), pl.X.
Condition: The metal has been cleaned of corrosion but the surface is slightly pitted.
